facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 23, 1960, of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 103 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 23, 1960, of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 103 of 1959. O. Chatterjee and P. K. Chatterjee, for the appellant, K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, B. R. L. Iyengar and P. D. Menon, for the respondents.

facts.text: The appellant made an application to the State Government of Orissa in 1949 for grant of a mining lease for manganese ore over an area comprising 5400 acres situated in the district of Keonjhar.

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. The appellant made an application to the State Government of Orissa in 1949 for grant of a mining lease for manganese ore over an area comprising 5400 acres situated in the district of Keonjhar.

facts.text: The appellant was the first applicant for the lease of the aforesaid area.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the first applicant for the lease of the aforesaid area, and subsequently other persons applied for lease of the same area including Messrs. Tata Iron and Steel Company Limited hereinafter referred to as Tatas , the intervener in the present appeal.

facts.text: Subsequently other persons applied for lease of the same area including Messrs. Tata Iron and Steel Company Limited (Tatas), the intervener in the present appeal.

anchor.surface_text: , and subsequently other persons applied for lease of the same area including Messrs. Tata Iron and Steel Company Limited hereinafter referred to as Tatas , the intervener in the present appeal. The Government of Orissa decided to grant the lease in favour of Tatas and in January 1956 referred the matter to the Central Government for its approval under r. 32 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 hereinafter referred to as the Rules ,

facts.text: The Government of Orissa decided to grant the lease in favour of Tatas.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Orissa decided to grant the lease in favour of Tatas and in January 1956 referred the matter to the Central Government for its approval under r. 32 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 hereinafter referred to as the Rules , which lays down that if more than one application regarding the same land is received, preference shall be given to the application received first,

facts.text: In January 1956 the Government of Orissa referred the matter to the Central Government for its approval under r. 32 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: in favour of Tatas and in January 1956 referred the matter to the Central Government for its approval under r. 32 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 hereinafter referred to as the Rules , which lays down that if more than one application regarding the same land is received, preference shall be given to the application received first, unless the State Government, for any special reason, and with the prior approval of the Central Government decides to the contrary.

facts.text: The appellant made a representation to the Central Government against the recommendation of the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made a representation to the Central Government against the recommendation of the State Government. Eventually, on April 9, 1957, the Central Government turned down the recommendation of the State Government about the grant of the mining lease to Tatas.

facts.text: On April 9, 1957, the Central Government turned down the recommendation of the State Government about the grant of the mining lease to Tatas.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, on April 9, 1957, the Central Government turned down the recommendation of the State Government about the grant of the mining lease to Tatas. It also directed that the applications received prior to the application of Tatas should be considered according to the Rules but added that in case the Government of Orissa desired to work the area on a departmental basis, the Central Government would have no objection to consider a proposal for that purpose.

facts.text: The Central Government directed that the applications received prior to the application of Tatas should be considered according to the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: It also directed that the applications received prior to the application of Tatas should be considered according to the Rules but added that in case the Government of Orissa desired to work the area on a departmental basis, the Central Government would have no objection to consider a proposal for that purpose.

facts.text: The State Government rejected the application of the appellant in December 1957 on the ground that the State Government proposed to arrange for the exploitation of the area in the public sector.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the State Government rejected the application of the appellant in December 1957 on the ground that the State Government proposed to arrange for the exploitation of the area in the public sector. This was followed by an application for review to the Central Government under r. 57 of the Rules.

facts.text: The appellant filed an application for review to the Central Government under r. 57 of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by an application for review to the Central Government under r. 57 of the Rules. This application was rejected by the Central Government in June 1969.

facts.text: The Central Government rejected the review application in June 1969.

anchor.surface_text: This application was rejected by the Central Government in June 1969. Thereupon the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court in July 1959.

facts.text: The appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court in July 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court in July 1959. This petition was dismissed by the High Court on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to deal with the matter under Art. 226 as the final order in the case was passed by the Central Government which was located beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the petition on the ground that it had no jurisdiction as the final order was passed by the Central Government beyond its territorial jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: This petition was dismissed by the High Court on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to deal with the matter under Art. 226 as the final order in the case was passed by the Central Government which was located beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court.

facts.text: The appellant applied to the High Court for a certificate to appeal to this Court, which was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court for a certificate to appeal to this Court, which was rejected. He then asked for special leave from this Court, which was granted and that is how the matter has come up before us.

facts.text: The Supreme Court granted special leave.

anchor.surface_text: He then asked for special leave from this Court, which was granted and that is how the matter has come up before us. The main question raised before us is the limit of the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 in circumstances like those in the present case.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 23, 1960, of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 103 of 1959. O. Chatterjee and P. K. Chatterjee, for the appellant, K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, B. R. L. Iyengar and P. D. Menon, for the respondents.

Thereupon the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court in July 1959. This petition was dismissed by the High Court on the ground that it had numberjurisdiction to deal with the matter under Art. 226 as the final order in the case was passed by the Central Government which was located beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court.

The contention on behalf of the appellant is that as the Central Government had merely dismissed the review petition, the effective order rejecting the appellants application for the mining lease was that of the State Government and therefore the High Court would have jurisdiction to grant a writ under Art. 226,

concepts.interpretation: High Court jurisdiction limited where final order by authority outside territorial jurisdiction

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: n passed by certain inferior authorities within the territories subject to the jurisdiction of the High Courts companycerned, but they had been taken

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled by a series of decisions of this Court beginning with Saka Venkata Subba Raos case 1  that there is two-fold limitation on the power of the High Court to grant a writ under Art. 226. These limitation are firstly that the power is to be exercised throughout the territories in relation to which the High Court exercise jurisdiction, that is to say, the writs issued by the High Court cannot run beyond the territories subject to its jurisdiction, and secondly, that the person or authority to whom the High Court is empowered to issue such writs must be within those territories, which clearly implies that they must be amenable to its jurisdiction either by residence or location within those territories.

concepts.interpretation: Two-fold limitation: (i) power exercised only within territories of jurisdiction, writs do not run beyond; (ii) person or authority must be within territories and amenable to jurisdiction by residence or location

issues.text: What is the limit of the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 in circumstances like those in the present case?

anchor.surface_text: The main question raised before us is the limit of the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 in circumstances like those in the present case.

issues.answer: Two-fold territorial limitation applies; no jurisdiction where final order by Central Government outside territory

issues.text: Whether the effective order rejecting the appellant's application for the mining lease was that of the State Government, given the Central Government's dismissal of the review petition, such that the High Court would have jurisdiction under Art. 226?

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellant is that as the Central Government had merely dismissed the review petition, the effective order rejecting the appellants application for the mining lease was that of the State Government and therefore the High Court would have jurisdiction to grant a writ under Art. 226,

issues.text: Whether the principle of merger applies such that the State Government's order merged in the Central Government's order on review, depriving the High Court of jurisdiction under Art. 226?

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant however relies on the decision in Mohd. Noohs case  2  where it was held that it was not correct to say that an order of dismissal passed on April 20, 1948, merged in the order in appeal therefrom passed in May 1949,

issues.text: Whether, under r. 60 of the Rules, the Central Government's order on review under r. 59 is final and prevails over the State Government's order?

anchor.surface_text: This is made clear by r. 60 of the Rules, which provides that the order of the Central Government under Rule 59 and subject only to such order, any order of a State Government under these rules, shall be final.

arguments.claim: The High Court had no jurisdiction under Art. 226 to deal with the matter as the final order was passed by the Central Government located beyond its territorial jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court in July 1959. This petition was dismissed by the High Court on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to deal with the matter under Art. 226 as the final order in the case was passed by the Central Government which was located beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court was right; final order by Central Government not within territory; confirmed by r.60

arguments.claim: The effective order rejecting the appellant's application was that of the State Government since Central Government merely dismissed the review petition; High Court has jurisdiction under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellant is that as the Central Government had merely dismissed the review petition, the effective order rejecting the appellants application for the mining lease was that of the State Government and therefore the High Court would have jurisdiction to grant a writ under Art. 226, and that the principle laid down in Election Commission India v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao l  would not apply.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: application for the mining lease was that of the State Government and therefore the High Court would have jurisdiction to grant a writ under Art. 226

arguments.court_reasoning: Two-fold territorial limitation applies; State order not final due to r.60 making Central review order prevail

arguments.claim: Principle in Saka Venkata Subba Rao does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: and that the principle laid down in Election Commission India v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao l  would not apply. Reliance in this connection has been placed on the decision of this Court in The State of Uttar Pradesh v. Mohammed Nooh 2 .

arguments.court_reasoning: Principle reaffirmed; applies here as final authority outside territory

arguments.claim: By analogy to Mohd. Nooh, State Government order did not merge in Central Government review order; High Court jurisdiction exists.

arguments.claim: There is a two-fold limitation on High Court power under Art. 226: writs cannot run beyond territories; authority must be within territories and amenable to jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled by a series of decisions of this Court beginning with Saka Venkata Subba Raos case 1  that there is two-fold limitation on the power of the High Court to grant a writ under Art. 226. These limitation are firstly that the power is to be exercised throughout the territories in relation to which the High Court exercise jurisdiction,

arguments.claim: Principle of merger does not apply to orders of departmental tribunals as in Mohd. Nooh; State order operative on own strength but here overridden by r.60.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the principle of Mohd. Noohs Case 1  cannot apply in the circumstances of the present case. The question there was whether the High Court would have power to issue a writ under Art. 226 in respect of a dismissal which was effective from 1948,

arguments.claim: Writ against inferior State authority would be infructuous as superior Central authority order outside jurisdiction remains operative.

anchor.surface_text: In those circumstances the High Courts had held that the order of the inferior authorities had merged in the orders of the authorities. This Court apparently approved of the view taken by the High Courts in those cases on the ground that a writ against the inferior authority within the territories could not be of any avail

arguments.claim: Under r.60, Central Government order under r.59 is final and prevails over State Government order; thus final order is Central's.

anchor.surface_text: This is made clear by r. 60 of the Rules, which provides that the order of the Central Government under Rule 59 and subject only to such order, any order of a State Government under these rules, shall be final. Clearly therefore r. 60 provides that where there is a review petition against the order passed

arguments.claim: High Court correctly held no jurisdiction as final order by Central Government not within its territories.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we are of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that it had no jurisdiction to issue a writ under Art. 226 in the present case as the final order in this case was that of the Central Government which was not situate within the territories

holdings.text: There is a two-fold limitation on the power of the High Court to grant a writ under Art. 226: firstly, the power is to be exercised throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction (writs cannot run beyond those territories); secondly, the person or authority must be within those territories and amenable to its jurisdiction by residence or location.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled by a series of decisions of this Court beginning with Saka Venkata Subba Raos case 1  that there is two-fold limitation on the power of the High Court to grant a writ under Art. 226. These limitation are firstly that the power is to be exercised throughout the territories in relation to which the High Court exercise jurisdiction, that is to say, the writs issued by the High Court cannot run beyond the territories subject to its jurisdiction, and secondly, that the person or authority to whom the High Court is empowered to issue such writs must be within those territories, which clearly implies that they must be amenable to its jurisdiction either by residence or location within those territories.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well settled law reaffirmed by series of Supreme Court decisions beginning with Election Commission v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao and recently in Lt. Col. Khajoor Singh v. Union of India.

holdings.text: The High Court had no power to grant a writ under Art. 226 as the final order was passed by the Central Government, which is not located within the territories over which the High Court has jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie, therefore, as the final order in this case was passed by the Central Government which is not located within the territories over which the High Court has jurisdiction, the High Court will have no power to grant a writ in this case. Learned counsel for the appellant however relies on the decision in Mohd. Noohs case  2  where it was held that it was not correct to say that an order of dismissal passed on April 20, 1948, merged in the order in appeal therefrom passed in May 1949,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of the two-fold territorial limitation under Art. 226 to the facts of the case.

holdings.text: The principle in Mohd. Nooh's case that the principle of merger does not apply to departmental orders does not deprive the Central Government's order of finality in this case.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the principle of Mohd. Noohs Case 1  cannot apply in the circumstances of the present case. The question there was whether the High Court would have power to issue a writ under Art. 226 in respect of a dismissal which was effective from 1948, simply because the revision against the order of dismissal was dismissed by the State Government in April 1950 after the Constitution came into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished on facts (pre-Constitution dismissal) and because principle of merger does not apply to departmental tribunals, but r.60 independently makes Central order final.

holdings.text: A writ against the State Government (inferior authority within jurisdiction) would be infructuous as the Central Government's superior order outside jurisdiction would remain operative.

anchor.surface_text: This Court apparently approved of the view taken by the High Courts in those cases on the ground that a writ against the inferior authority within the territories could not be of any avail to the petitioners concerned in those cases and could give them no relief for the orders of the superior authority outside the jurisdiction would remain outstanding and operative against them. Therefore, as no writs could be issued against the outside authorities, this Court was of the view that the High Courts were right in dismissing the petitions,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Position analogous to cases approved in A. Thangal Kunju Musaliar v. M. Venkitachalam Potti where writ against inferior futile due to overriding superior order.

holdings.text: Under r.60 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, the order of the Central Government under r.59 prevails over and is final in respect of any State Government order.

anchor.surface_text: This is made clear by r. 60 of the Rules, which provides that the order of the Central Government under Rule 59 and subject only to such order, any order of a State Government under these rules, shall be final. Clearly therefore r. 60 provides that where there is a review petition against the order passed in the first instance by the State Government, the order of the Central Government passed in review would prevail and would be the final order dealing with an application for a mining lease under the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of r.60 establishes that Central review order is effective and final, independent of merger doctrine.

holdings.text: The Orissa High Court correctly held it had no jurisdiction under Art. 226 to entertain the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we are of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that it had no jurisdiction to issue a writ under Art. 226 in the present case as the final order in this case was that of the Central Government which was not situate within the territories over which the High Court has jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmed by two-fold Art.226 limitation, r.60 finality of Central order, and infructuousness of writ against State.

anchor.surface_text: nkata Subba Raos case 1  that there is two-fold limitation on the power of the High Court to grant a writ under Art. 226. These limitation are firstly

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled by a series of decisions of this Court beginning with Saka Venkata Subba Raos case 1  that there is two-fold limitation on the power of the High Court to grant a writ under Art. 226. These limitation are firstly that the power is to be exercised throughout the territories in relation to which the High Court exercise jurisdiction, that is to say, the writs issued by the High Court cannot run beyond the territories subject to its jurisdiction, and secondly, that the person or authority to whom the High Court is empowered to issue such writs must be within those territories, which clearly implies that they must be amenable to its jurisdiction either by residence or location within those territories.

In these circumstances we are of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that it had numberjurisdiction to issue a writ under Art. 226 in the present case as the final order in this case was that of the Central Government

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie, therefore, as the final order in this case was passed by the Central Government which is not located within the territories over which the High Court has jurisdiction, the High Court will have no power to grant a writ in this case. Learned counsel for the appellant however relies on the decision in Mohd. Noohs case  2  where it was held that it was not correct to say that an order of dismissal passed on April 20, 1948, merged in the order in appeal therefrom passed in May 1949,

In these circumstances we are of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that it had numberjurisdiction to issue a writ under Art. 226 in the present case as the final order in this case was that of the Central Government

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the principle of Mohd. Noohs Case 1  cannot apply in the circumstances of the present case. The question there was whether the High Court would have power to issue a writ under Art. 226 in respect of a dismissal which was effective from 1948, simply because the revision against the order of dismissal was dismissed by the State Government in April 1950 after the Constitution came into force.

In these circumstances we are of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that it had numberjurisdiction to issue a writ under Art. 226 in the present case as the final order in this case was that of the Central Government
ar to that envisaged above. The Orissa Government rejected the application of the appellant for grant of the mining lease. The appellant being aggriev

anchor.surface_text: This Court apparently approved of the view taken by the High Courts in those cases on the ground that a writ against the inferior authority within the territories could not be of any avail to the petitioners concerned in those cases and could give them no relief for the orders of the superior authority outside the jurisdiction would remain outstanding and operative against them. Therefore, as no writs could be issued against the outside authorities, this Court was of the view that the High Courts were right in dismissing the petitions,

In these circumstances we are of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that it had numberjurisdiction to issue a writ under Art. 226 in the present case as the final order in this case was that of the Central Government

edges.explanation: The holding explicitly states the legal position under r.60 that directly answers and resolves the issue regarding the finality and prevalence of the Central Government's order.

anchor.surface_text: This is made clear by r. 60 of the Rules, which provides that the order of the Central Government under Rule 59 and subject only to such order, any order of a State Government under these rules, shall be final. Clearly therefore r. 60 provides that where there is a review petition against the order passed in the first instance by the State Government, the order of the Central Government passed in review would prevail and would be the final order dealing with an application for a mining lease under the Rules.

In these circumstances we are of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that it had numberjurisdiction to issue a writ under Art. 226 in the present case as the final order in this case was that of the Central Government

In these circumstances we are of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that it had numberjurisdiction to issue a writ under Art. 226 in the present case as the final order in this case was that of the Central Government
